div1.p: Your second letter embarrassed me, but I almost forgive my procrastination since it brought me second mellow note in which I find my pleasure surpasses my shame.

I postponed mailing the books because I hadn't written. I didn't write because I had put out request to several people to hand me one or two sentences putting in writing comments made to me about the lift meeting you and hearing you gave them. Since two of these are still not in hand I've waited. The writers very sincerely want to give
20
me statements but we live in a busy world and the firsthugs of our hearts do not always get first attention.

Springfield is still talking about the day. I have heard praise and gratitude from the three groups before whom the poet, Neihardt, and the man Neihardt apeared. The man is an able speaker and reader. There was full preparation of the audience before each reading of the poems. Easter was especially praised. But it was evident that both youth and adults felt something more than intellectual pleasure. With simple clearness Mr. Neihardt budged the translation from objective details over to transcendental experiences which defy comprehension. His quiet faith in the divinity within men gave the uplift human hearts crave. The Spring-
21
field English club is proud to have brought Mr. Neihardt and the audiences express themselves as deeply grateful.
That testimonial you may use, trim or amend under my name or the name of the Springfield English Club. Mildred Norton 1943 1944 President

And now for my own personal statement to the Neihardts. You were too generous with your time and yourself. Personally hungry for someone in touch with untangible realities, I found understanding of my experiences — too sacred to risk telling to the uninitiated. I am shy and silent about sharing what I also feel too
22
valuable to hide secretively. You gave me courage in my own faith in visions and spiritual contacts.

Now I quote exactly:
My much loved friend wrote this note "Dear Elizabeth: In thinking over Dr. Neihardt's visit to Springfield it is the spiritual "left" which he gave in his informal afternoon talk at your home which lives in my mind. The simple humility with which he told of the religious insight he received from his long hours of communion with Black Elk was impressive. The portions of the Messiah which he read beautifully phrased this message. The glimpses Dr. Neihardt gave of his own personal life and work evidenced the sincerity of his belief in the message in the Messiah. For this rather intimate revealing of such a fine philosophy of life, I am greateful. Most sincerely, Lucy C. Williams

"Being completely frank, I must admit that even after three semesters of literature, I had no interests in poets or poetry of any kind until I heard Neihardt. Poetry, which I had always connected with the feminine, has become real and close to life. The interest stirred by Neihardt has led me to the discovery of Walt Whitman"
James Maddox (H.S. Senior)

"Books betray the character of their authors. In the epic literature of Neihardt I have detected a keen interest for human life, a hungry desire for the freshness of nature, and a sincere lif love for the philosophical,"
Jack Baldwin (Senior)

"When I was very young, I got a big thrill from the stories of pioneers, Indian Wars and the old West. As I progressed in years, I grew out of this, and this type of story became distasteful to me. For the last three years I have heartily condemned any story of cowboys, Indians, traders or trappers.
